steps.notes: Cast bearing races and rolling elements from bearing steel
Machine and heat treat bearing components to HRC 58-64
Precision grind races and rolling elements to final tolerances
Assemble bearings with cage, lubricate, seal, and test

recipe_def.assumptions: Heavy-duty bearing set (4 kg) for large motors and machinery; precision ground races and rolling elements; heat-treated to bearing-grade hardness; includes lubrication and final testing.
recipe_def.notes: Comprehensive 13-step recipe covering steel processing, precision machining, ball/roller forming, heat treatment, assembly, lubrication, and testing. Suitable for 70-100mm bore heavy industrial bearings.

steps.notes: Hot forge hex heads on bolt blanks and upset nut blanks using dies
Cut external threads on bolts (M6-M12) and tap internal threads in nuts using lathes and tapping machines
Stamp flat washers and lock washers from steel sheet stock using progressive dies
Heat treat bolts and lock washers for hardness and spring properties (austenitizing, quenching, tempering)
Inspect heat-treated fasteners for hardness and dimensional checks
Sort fasteners by size (M6, M8, M10, M12), count, and kit into organized container

recipe_def.assumptions:
Complete fastener manufacturing from steel stock to finished kit. Process integrates:
- Hot forging for head formation (hex heads on bolts, upset blanks for nuts)
- Thread cutting via single-point turning (bolts) and tapping (nuts)
- Sheet metal stamping for washer production
- Heat treatment for strength and hardness
- Final inspection and kitting

Input materials: 2.0 kg steel stock (1.0 kg bar/billet, 1.0 kg sheet)
Output: 1.0 kg complete fastener kit per BOM specification
Scrap rate: ~50% from machining chips and stamping waste (conservative placeholder)
recipe_def.notes:
Six-step recipe for fastener_kit_medium production.

Kit composition per bom_fastener_kit_medium_v0:
- 720g hex bolts M6-M12 in various lengths (76 pieces total)
- 180g hex nuts M6-M12 (135 pieces total)
- 75g flat washers M6-M12 (135 pieces total)
- 30g lock washers M6-M12 (60 pieces total)
Total: ~366 fasteners, 1.0 kg net weight

Manufacturing process details:
1. Forging: Form hex heads on bolt blanks, upset nut blanks for adequate thread engagement
2. Threading: Cut external threads on bolts (dies or single-point), tap nuts (spiral point taps)
3. Washer stamping: Progressive die stamps flat and lock washers from sheet
4. Heat treatment: Quench and temper bolts to grade 8.8 equivalent, harden lock washers
5. Inspection: Verify hardness and dimensional checks
6. Kitting: Sort by size, verify counts, package in compartmented container

Total time: ~8 hours (primarily sequential, some parallel opportunity for washers)
References detailed specification in design/memos/fastener_kit_specification.md
Most commonly used fastener kit in the KB (107 BOMs reference this item)

steps.notes: Hall-Hroult electrolysis at ~960C. Very energy-intensive (15 kWh/kg)

inputs.notes: Aluminum oxide extracted from highland regolith
Flux to lower melting point (~90% recycled)

recipe_def.assumptions:
Hall-Hroult process produces aluminum suitable for structural applications.
Cryolite flux is 90% recyclable. Carbon anode consumption rate is 0.5 kg per kg aluminum.
Energy requirement: 15 kWh/kg is realistic for electrolytic aluminum production.
recipe_def.notes:
Aluminum alloy ingot production via Hall-Hroult electrolysis from alumina.

This is the standard industrial process for primary aluminum production.
Extremely energy-intensive (15 kWh/kg output) but enables local aluminum
production from lunar highland regolith.

Process chain from regolith:
1. Highland regolith (100 kg)  alumina extraction  12 kg alumina
2. Alumina (2 kg)  Hall-Hroult smelting  1 kg aluminum ingot
3. Therefore: ~17 kg regolith  1 kg aluminum ingot

Replaces placeholder recipe that incorrectly used generic melting/casting.

Link coil insulation material to production process coil_insulation_production_v0 to resolve no_recipe gap.
Wind aluminum wire with insulation into motor coils. 28.4 kg wire + 1.4 kg insulation  27 kg coils + 2.8 kg scrap.
Form steel motor housing from iron. 19.2 kg iron  18 kg housing + 1.2 kg scrap.

steps.notes: Forge rough blank from steel stock bar or billet to approximate shaft shape
Turn and bore to bearing journals and keyway features
Final tolerances and surface finish on shaft bearing surfaces

recipe_def.assumptions: Use steel stock bar or billet; final motor shaft geometry matches journal and keyway specs; tolerances defined by machining_finish_basic_v0

recipe_def.name: Motor shaft (steel)  basic v0

steps.notes: Stamp stator/rotor laminations from electrical steel sheet (40 kg  38 kg)
Wind aluminum coils for medium motor (28.4 kg wire + insulation  27 kg coils)
Assemble motor from laminations, coils, housing, shaft, bearings, and fasteners

recipe_def.assumptions:
90 kg medium drive motor for automated machinery.

Material requirements (total ~92.4 kg input):
- Electrical steel sheet: 40 kg (for laminations)
- Aluminum wire: 28.4 kg (for windings)
- Coil insulation: 1.4 kg (imported or produced)
- Motor housing steel: 15 kg
- Motor shaft steel: 5 kg
- Bearing set heavy: 4 kg
- Fastener kit medium: 1 kg

Output: 1 drive_motor_medium unit (90 kg nominal) + ~2.4 kg scrap/loss

This recipe uses the proven processes from motor_electric_small production
but scaled up for the larger motor size.
recipe_def.notes:
Three-step recipe for medium electric drive motor using detailed process flows.

Replaces recipe_drive_motor_medium_v0 which used placeholder processes.

Total production time: ~19 hours
- Lamination stamping: 2 hr
- Coil winding: 13 hr (precision work)
- Final assembly and test: 4 hr

ISRU potential: 96% by mass (only coil insulation imported)

recipe_def.assumptions: Generic medium-sized gear set; gear cutting covers blank machining and tooth cutting; heat treatment optional
recipe_def.notes:
Production of medium gear set from steel bar stock.

Process:
1. Cut gear blanks from steel bar stock (lathe/mill)
2. Cut gear teeth (gear hobbing or milling)
3. Heat treat for hardness (optional, depends on application)
4. Finish and inspect

Mass: ~60 kg finished gears from 65 kg steel stock (8% machining loss)
